images.caption: Figure 1:With relative EEF action space and full task observation, State-free Policies demonstrate significantly improved spatial generalization ability compared to state-based policies. To handle complex scenarios, the full task observation is implemented by dual wide-angle wrist-cameras.
Figure 2:(a) Normal wrist-camera setting. Sometimes the target may not be visible. (b) Dual wide-angle wrist-cameras setting. It provides sufficient observations of the task.

Figure 3:Overview of our robot embodiments and representative tasks, including “Pick&\&Place” tasks, more challenging “Fold Shirt” and “Fetch Bottle” task. These tasks span a wide range of robot embodiments: a2×82\times 8DoF human-like dual-arm robot, a2×72\times 7DoF dual-arm Arx5 robotic arm system, and a 26 DoF whole-body robot.

Figure 4:Task-relevant object locations illustration in task“Pick Pen”. During training, the pen holder is fixed. For horizontal generalization, we keep the pen location range unchanged and shift the pen holder by 5 cm and 10 cm to compute the average success rate.

Figure 5:The height and horizontal generalization (written as Gen.) performances across 3 real-world“Pick&\&Place”tasks. With full task observation, State-free Policies show significantly improved spatial generalization than state-based policies.
Figure 6:Evaluation success rates (in-domain) on the“Pick Pen”task with varying amounts of fine-tuning data.
